image.altText: A composite of a woman with long blonde hair, and a young person holding an Adidas sneaker.

items.synopsis: When Byron Bay woman Sarah Luke found out her personal details had been shared on the dark web, she never imagined it would lead to two US court actions and a million-dollar damages bill.

title.children: Data breach victim told to pay Adidas, National Basketball Association $US1.2m by US courts

image.altText: The sign out of the front of the building and the crest, with an autumnal tree nearby and a blue sky beyond.

items.synopsis: Christopher Roy Weaver, 40, faces court nearly two years after the death of Laura Crncevic of a heroin overdose.

title.children: Canberra man charged with manslaughter over heroin overdose that killed partner nearly two years ago

image.altText: A candle that looks like a dessert, in a glass.

items.synopsis: Social enterprise Crafting My Story is aiming to create a supportive sisterhood of culturally diverse women in Australia and overseas making handmade, environmentally sustainable works.

title.children: Making these edible-looking candles helps Delani connect with her community and be a better mum

image.altText: A woman celebrates scoring a goal

items.synopsis: It's day six of the Women's World Cup, featuring co-hosts New Zealand and Norway, who knocked the Matildas out of the last World Cup. But first, it's the Group H match between Colombia and South Korea. Follow live.

title.children: Inspirational teen star scores for Colombia in its World Cup opener

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Casey Phair enters the fray for South Korea as a substitute for Choe Yuri, and becomes the youngest player at a men's or Women's World Cup at just 16 years and 26 days old.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A new youngest ever World Cup player

children.content: Casey Phair enters the fray for South Korea as a substitute for Choe Yuri, and becomes the youngest player at a men's or Women's World Cup at just 16 years and 26 days old.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Catalina Usme kicked things off from the spot before a strike from teen sensation Linda Caceido made it 2-0 for the South Americans. The crowd at the Sydney Football Stadium is going off, with the a distinct fluoro yellow tinge in the stands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Colombia 2-0 South Korea

props.alt: A Colombian fans holds up a lion's head in the stands at Women's World Cup.

children.content: (ABC News: Brendan Esposito)
Catalina Usme kicked things off from the spot before a strike from teen sensation Linda Caceido made it 2-0 for the South Americans.
The crowd at the Sydney Football Stadium is going off, with the a distinct fluoro yellow tinge in the stands.

props.alt: A wide shot of Colombia playing South Korea at the Sydney Football Stadium with fans in the stands.

children.content: (Getty)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And it's another penalty! The ninth awarded for the tournament and the fifth scored. There can be no debate about this one though, with Shim Seoyeon clearly handballing as she blocked a shot. And Catalina Usme coolly sotted low to the left as Yoon Younggeul went the wrong way.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 30' Colombia hits the lead

children.content: And it's another penalty! The ninth awarded for the tournament and the fifth scored.

props.alt: A sign supporting Colombia at the Women's World Cup.

children.content: This sign reads "Hello family. Go girls." Yeah, I'm kinda bilingual.
(Getty)
There can be no debate about this one though, with
Shim Seoyeon clearly handballing as she blocked a shot.
And Catalina Usme coolly sotted low to the left as Yoon Younggeul went the wrong way.

image.altText: A composite photo of two women and two men.

items.synopsis: Police have laid out the chain of events they will allege led to a horror triple fatal north of the Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Good Samaritan chased into oncoming traffic before triple fatal crash, police allege

image.altText: A drone shot of Lake Menindee glowing orange at sunset.

items.synopsis: Water Minister Tanya Plibersek says the $13 billion Murray-Darling Basin Plan deadline must be extended.

title.children: Basin Plan targets won't be met on time, says water minister

image.altText: A composite image of Veena Sahajwalla on the left, Craig Reucassel in the middle and Nina Gbor on the right

items.synopsis: Ahead of tonight's premiere of War On Waste, host Craig Reucassel, eco stylist Nina Gbor and scientist Veena Sahajwalla are on deck to answer your recycling questions, bust myths, and provide the inspiration to take action.

title.children: From commercial to household rubbish — how can we fight the war on waste? Join our live Q&A

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Is there a case for burning plastics instead of recycling?  is there an energy source from burning plastics that is enviromentally sound.
 - Cat. Thanks for the question Cat! I've put it to Professor Veena Sahajwalla for her advice: Every time you think about burning plastic to produce energy, you have to think about it as burning oil because plastic comes from oil. Now that we have created all of this plastic, the best thing we can do is not put it into landfill, not burn it, because by burning it we're actually releasing carbon emissions into the environment. But by keeping a plastic in a solid state where it can be used for remanufacturing, we’re making sure we're actually promoting circularity. Creating useful products through remanufacturing is one way to make sure all of that plastic legacy waste that is now sitting in our landfills can actually be converted into value-added products. It is up to us to choose products that are packaged sustainably. Reject products that have excessive plastic packaging like fruit in plastic containers and single use plastic bags for cucumbers and tomatoes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is there a case for burning our plastics?

children.content: Is there a case for burning plastics instead of recycling?  is there an energy source from burning plastics that is enviromentally sound.
- Cat
Thanks for the question Cat!
I've put it to
Professor Veena Sahajwalla
for her advice:

Every time you think about burning plastic to produce energy, you have to think about it as burning oil because plastic comes from oil. Now that we have created all of this plastic, the best thing we can do is not put it into landfill, not burn it, because by burning it we're actually releasing carbon emissions into the environment.

But by keeping a plastic in a solid state where it can be used for remanufacturing, we’re making sure we're actually promoting circularity. Creating useful products through remanufacturing is one way to make sure all of that plastic legacy waste that is now sitting in our landfills can actually be converted into value-added products.

It is up to us to choose products that are packaged sustainably. Reject products that have excessive plastic packaging like fruit in plastic containers and single use plastic bags for cucumbers and tomatoes.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Thank you pannelists for all the good work you do. I know its only one part of the solution but how do we consumers find out about buying goods using less, or no plastic, and/or products using alternatives to the 'bad' non-degradable plastics? Is there a good website or other place to go for the info? - Edwin Carr. Thanks Edwin for that question. I've passed it on to Craig, here's his take: Hi Edwin, you should find some tips on the Plastic Free July website. You can search for bulk food stores in your area, where you bring your own bottles and containers and fill them up with foods and other products. There are also a number of new companies that seek to reduce plastic by selling you refillable containers and getting you to mail back the packaging used to refill them.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do we go about avoiding plastics?

children.content: Thank you pannelists for all the good work you do. I know its only one part of the solution but how do we consumers find out about buying goods using less, or no plastic, and/or products using alternatives to the 'bad' non-degradable plastics? Is there a good website or other place to go for the info?
- Edwin Carr
Thanks Edwin for that question.
I've passed it on to
Craig
, here's his take:
Hi Edwin, you should find some tips on the
Plastic Free July website

You can search for bulk food stores in your area, where you bring your own bottles and containers and fill them up with foods and other products. There are also a number of new companies that seek to reduce plastic by selling you
refillable
containers and getting you to mail back the packaging used to refill them.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: How does Australia rank internationally in terms of its recycling technology and uptake?  - Steph. Thanks for your question Steph! Professor Veena Sahajwalla has this to say: There is great technology and science being developed right here in Australia that we can take advantage of to find fit-for-purpose solutions, especially with the unique challenges that Australia’s landscape and markets present. The Australian Research Council is supporting cutting-edge science, bringing together industry and researchers, to address complex waste challenges. I am privileged to be directing one of these research centres, SMaRT Centre, in creating microfactories and the science of microrecycling to tackle some our most challenging waste issues.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How does Australia rank internationally on recycling?

children.content: How does Australia rank internationally in terms of its recycling technology and uptake?
- Steph
Thanks for your question Steph!
Professor Veena Sahajwalla
has this to say:

There is great technology and science being developed right here in Australia that we can take advantage of to find fit-for-purpose solutions, especially with the unique challenges that Australia’s landscape and markets present. The Australian Research Council is supporting cutting-edge science, bringing together industry and researchers, to address complex waste challenges. I am privileged to be directing one of these research centres, SMaRT Centre, in creating microfactories and the science of microrecycling to tackle some our most challenging waste issues.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a cold winter in many parts of Australia and the cost of heating your home has surged after electricity price increases this month. Research by consumer finance website Finder shows that South Australians are being worst hit by the increase in power prices with an annual estimated rise of more than $800. Here's the breakdown: South Australia: estimated price rise of 22% to 63%. A more than $800 annual increase for some customers. New South Wales: bills went up by 15% to 36%. An increase of up to $420 a year. Victoria: power prices rose by 22% to 31% with an annual price increase of up to $396. Queensland: estimated price increases of 8% to 41% with an annual price rise of $548. Saving money Finder surveyed 1,090 people and found 79% are planning to cut back on their energy usage over winter to save money. 56% plan to switch off lights and power points when not in use 54% plan to reduce use of heaters and air conditioners 21% switch to energy saving lightbulbs 9% will work from the office instead of home 9% switch electricity or gas providers Finder recommends you chose the right heater for your home and says reverse-cycle air conditioners are the cheapest to run. It also recommends that you compare and switch energy plans and look for rebates and concessions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Power bills jump by more than $800 a year

children.content: It's a cold winter in many parts of Australia and the cost of heating your home has surged after electricity price increases this month.
Research by consumer finance website Finder shows that South Australians are being worst hit by the increase in power prices with an annual estimated rise of more than $800.
Here's the breakdown:
South Australia:
estimated price rise of 22% to 63%.
A more than $800 annual increase for some customers.
New South Wales:
bills went up by 15% to 36%.
An increase of up to $420 a year.
Victoria:
power prices rose by 22% to 31% with an annual price increase of up to $396.
Queensland:
estimated price increases of 8% to 41% with an annual price rise of $548.
Saving money
Finder surveyed 1,090 people and found 79% are planning to cut back on their energy usage over winter to save money.
56% plan to switch off lights and power points when not in use
54% plan to reduce use of heaters and air conditioners
21% switch to energy saving lightbulbs
9% will work from the office instead of home
9% switch electricity or gas providers
Finder recommends you chose the right heater for your home and says reverse-cycle air conditioners are the cheapest to run.
It also recommends that you compare and switch energy plans and look for rebates and concessions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A few hours into trade and the local share market is still up by around 0.3 per cent, so a fairly modest gain. That's despite a really standout session for the miners, more than recouping some of the losses they posted yesterday — shares in Fortescue are up 5 per cent, Rio 's up 4.1 per cent and BHP has gained 3.8 per cent. Energy stocks are on the up, with Santos gaining 1.1 per cent so far. Despite the good performances, the gains across the broader index are being capped by falls in the financials sector — shares in Westpac have dropped 1.4 per cent. And most other sectors are posting losses as well. 119 of the top 200 stocks are in the red as it stands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX hanging onto modest gain, Fortescue up 5%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're a Spotify paid subscriber, you'll notice an extra dollar coming out of your account in coming months. Australia is one of a slew of countries being hit with the price hike by the music streaming service, which includes lifting the price of an individual premium membership from $11.99 to $12.99. Existing subscribers will get a one-month grace period before the charge increased comes out of their account. In an announcement, Spotify trumpeted its latest innovations, including its new 'AI DJ', in explaining the decision. During trade on Wall Street overnight, Spotify shares fell 4.7 per cent on the news, which comes ahead of its quarterly earnings report to be released Tuesday US time. But hey, it wasn't all bad news according to analysts from JP Morgan, who expect a 10 per cent increase in annualised revenue for the streaming giant. So out of your account and into Spotify's!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Spotify hikes prices on its premium subscription

children.content: If you're a
Spotify

Australia is one of a slew of countries being hit with the price hike by the music streaming service, which includes
lifting the price of an individual premium membership from $11.99 to $12.99
Existing subscribers will get a one-month grace period
before the charge increased comes out of their account.
In an announcement, Spotify trumpeted its latest innovations, including its new 'AI DJ', in explaining the decision.
During trade on Wall Street overnight,
Spotify shares fell 4.7 per cent on the news
, which comes ahead of its quarterly earnings report to be released Tuesday US time.
But hey, it wasn't all bad news according to analysts from JP Morgan, who expect a 10 per cent increase in annualised revenue for the streaming giant.
So out of your account and into Spotify's!

image.altText: a man in a simple black jacket sits behind microphones

title.children: China's economy is in serious trouble — and it's bad news for Australia

image.altText: John margerison

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse showing stacks of soft plastics, with some closer up.

image.altText: A black and white graphic of a woman in profile, with a brain symbol over her head, with confused lightning shapes to her right.

image.altText: A commercial fridge filled with Coca Cola and other soft drinks.

image.altText: Independent candidate for Curtin Kate Chaney

title.children: Rare dolphin-adorned sarcophagus among tombs discovered at a Roman-era cemetery
